subtitle: New Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today, I'd like to talk about politics and consciousness.
Now, since 1986, I guess that's over 30 years I’ve been
creating videotape interviews
and the topics that I have covered traditionally have been philosophy, psychology,
health, science, and spirituality. I have avoided current events almost
entirely. I have avoided politics almost entirely. But, I do think
there is a time and place
for discussion about politics, not in terms of any political party, or any candidate or any
style of governing, but politics in general. One might say, the philosophy of politics. Now, I believe
everybody has a political
bias. Or else, they’re completely disinterested in politics, which is also a bias.
So, just in case you don't know, let me make it very clear: I am a lifelong
Democrat. I consider myself a liberal and I have always been. I have never voted for
anyone else other than a Democratic candidate in the
50 or more years since I have been
voting. That's where I stand. However, I also believe in tolerance.
I have had many people on the program whose political views are quite different from my own.
It's not a problem because normally we’re not discussing
politics. One person in particular is known to have rather extremist political views, but to my
awareness has never expressed them on this program in an interview with me. We talk about philosophy and
parapsychology and related issues.
So, my rule for engaging in discussions with people is that they have something
intelligent to say about the topics under
consideration.
There has been an argument, and it's an interesting one, by the famous philosopher of science,
Karl Popper, about tolerance. He said this: If you believe in tolerance, and I do,
then you have to be intolerant of people who are intolerant, because how else can we have a tolerant
society? I
disagree with Popper about that. I don't think that being
intolerant of people who are intolerant
really furthers the cause of
tolerance. It seems to just
aggravate it because it gives these people a platform to say, “Look at how I’m being treated!
You claim to be so tolerant, but you’re intolerant of my point of view.” It's amazing how many people
do share intolerant viewpoints.
I know, having grown up in a small Wisconsin town and being Jewish, I learned as a young child
that people I
never knew, knew that I was Jewish and didn't like it. I would get
adults sometimes saying very nasty
anti-Semitic remarks to me as a child. So, I’m well aware that
intolerance is deeply embedded in our community. I also know that
amongst people who are intolerant, they don't like
multiculturalism, they don't like
globalism. I happen to favor both. But I know a lot of these people think globalism and
multiculturalism are Jewish plots
designed to weaken their
view of what the world should be like. That it should be dominated by
white Protestant males, or something of that sort.
In any case,
why am I discussing this now with you? What is in all of this for you?
A couple of things. One is to begin to ask yourself, if you’re not clear where you stand
politically,
it's important to give that some thought. But there's a key.
My sense is that for every political
posture a person might take there is an equal and opposite posture somewhere.
Sometimes people flip back and forth very quickly. I think we've seen that in some of our recent politics, where
long held beliefs by certain groups can be easily flipped around.
The great philosopher
Hegel talked about the dialectic process, where you go from thesis to antithesis
to a new synthesis. And so,
that’s always going on politically -
left-wing, right-wing,
moderate -
left-wing, right-wing, moderate. It can kind of be like a cyclical activity, almost you might think like the
activity of the symbol of this very video
channel, the yin-yang, and even, I might say, the rainbow yin-yang. So,
politics in some ways can become very flexible for people. Positions change.
There is a sense in which you don't know whether or not you are on solid ground all the time with your political views, because circumstances
can change. I think the important thing in discussing
politics,
from my point of view, is that the discussion should be based on facts and
logic. And of course there is a role for emotion. People have very strong
feelings about things and those feelings need to be acknowledged and honored.
The simple way I think about it is that facts trump feelings.
And facts even trump logic. If you believe something is logical
but the facts are against you, well, the facts take priority. I think that's true in particular for people
who have very emotional feelings about psychic
functioning. They think it's just impossible.
Well, I think the facts trump that. They trump your logic and they trump your emotions, as far as
parapsychology is concerned. I think that
we ought to treat our politics the same way. It's very likely in today’s circumstances
where politics seems to be weighing so heavily on us, that I may
from time to time engage in it, maybe more often than I have in the past.
But, I want you to know, as a viewer that
however the politics is
being treated, I want it to be respectful and polite and factually based.
The previous segment of the “In Presence” series, when I talked about the
secrets of self-esteem, well, you may recall: one of those secrets is never to
devalue another human being.
I think that should especially apply when it comes to political
conversations. I know the temptation,
especially in politics, is to consider those people who disagree with you politically to be somehow
less human than you are.
If you feel that way, and I know I sometimes do, it's a good idea to check yourself.
So, I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you for being with me.
